The catalytic selective oxidation of biomass-derived platform chemicals into monomers offers a sustainable alternative pathway to fossil-based production of chemicals. Herein, mesoporous Al2O3 with dispersed Mo-V oxide catalysts were prepared through a solvent-free solid-state grinding method for the liquid phase oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride. The selective oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride was dependent on the Mo/V mole ratio of the catalyst, catalyst calcination temperature, and catalyst synthesis method. The synergistic interaction of Mo-V with Al2O3 was identified as crucial for enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity towards maleic anhydride. The reusability of the 25Mo1VA catalyst was studied over five catalytic cycles with a progressive loss of maleic anhydride yield due to the formation of surface carbonaceous species. However, the majority of maleic anhydride yield could be recovered utilizing a catalyst regeneration cycle (600 °C, 3 h). Graphical Abstract Keywords Mesoporous alumina Mo-V oxide catalyst Solvent-free solid-state catalyst synthesis Oxidation Furfural Maleic anhydride Data availability The data supporting this article have been included as part of the Supporting Information with additional experimental data and supporting figures available. Metadata (PXRD, Raman, TGA, XPS, Porosimetry and Catalysis) for this article is also available via the University of Liverpool data repository at 10.17638/datacat.liverpool.ac.uk/2816. 1 Introduction The rapid depletion of petroleum reserves and the growing environmental concerns linked to excessive fossil fuel consumption have positioned lignocellulosic biomass as a promising, eco-friendly, and renewable carbon source for energy, chemicals, and materials production [1,2]. While 181.5 billion tons of lignocellulosic biomass are generated annually worldwide, only a fraction (8.2 billion tons) is currently utilized [3]. This vast untapped resource presents a significant opportunity to produce bio-based chemicals as alternatives to petroleum-derived counterparts in industrial processes. Consequently, the catalytic conversion of renewable biomass into chemicals, fuels, and polymers has attracted considerable attention in recent years [4–6]. Furfural, a highly functional platform chemical derived from abundant agricultural waste, is produced commercially and serves as an attractive precursor for valuable products [7–9]. Among the various value-added chemicals and monomers synthesizable from furfural, maleic anhydride is particularly promising [10–13]. Maleic anhydride is a critical intermediate chemical employed in the production of unsaturated polyester resins, plasticizers, surface coatings, pharmaceuticals, and vinyl copolymers [14–18]. Traditionally, maleic anhydride is produced through gas-phase oxidation of petroleum-derived benzene using mixed oxides of molybdenum and vanadium in a heterogeneous catalytic system at temperatures ranging from 400 to 450 °C [19,20]. However, due to the carcinogenic nature of benzene, n-butane has emerged as an alternative fossil-based feedstock for producing maleic anhydride, utilizing a vanadium phosphorus mixed oxide catalytic system [21]. Nevertheless, there is a growing interest in synthesizing maleic anhydride from non-edible biomass due to environmental concerns and depletion of non-renewable resources associated with petroleum-derived products. Biomass-derived furfural, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF), levulinic acid, and bio-butanol have been identified as alternative feedstocks for maleic anhydride synthesis [22–27]. However, 5-HMF, levulinic acid, and biobutanol are still in the laboratory-scale production phase and cannot yet replace fossil resources for large-scale maleic anhydride synthesis. Additionally, these substrates suffer from higher carbon numbers, high cost, and challenging transformations. Alternatively, furfural, which is inexpensive and commercially available, can be used for the production of maleic anhydride via gas or liquid phase oxidation reactions, employing either homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts. While the oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride holds promise, it faces significant economic and environmental challenges. These include developing highly selective and stable heterogeneous catalysts and efficient reaction processes (batch and flow reactors). Liquid phase reactions could become more energy efficient than gas phase reactions, with a reduced energy costs associated with lower reaction temperatures and no requirement for the vaporization of liquid reagents and solvents [28,29]. However, further catalyst development is needed to achieve high yields of the desired product to ensure the potential benefits of liquid phase reactions are realized. Alonso-Fagúndez et al. reported a 73 % yield of maleic anhydride from the gas-phase oxidation of furfural at 320 °C using a VOx/Al2O3 catalyst [30,31]. Li et al. achieved approximately 90 % maleic anhydride yield at 10 vol% furfural in the feed by using a vanadium phosphorus oxide catalyst for the gas-phase oxidation of furfural at 360 °C [22]. Recently, Santander et al. investigated the effect of catalyst support for VOx surface dispersion for the partial oxidation of furfural, with various catalyst supports, including Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, and ZrO2 studied [32]. Notably, the VOx/Al2O3 and VOx/SiO2 catalysts exhibited a high maleic anhydride yield (50 %). However, despite the favorable maleic anhydride production in the gas-phase oxidation of furfural, the process suffers from limited catalyst stability and high reaction temperatures. The liquid-phase oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride using O2 as a terminal oxidant represents a low energy alternative. Lan et al. developed a homogeneous V-containing heteropoly acid (H₅PMo₁₀V₂O₄₀) in combination with the Lewis acid Cu(CF₃(SO₃)₂) catalyst for furfural oxidation in organic solvent reaction medium (acetonitrile/acetic acid) [33]. Although this catalytic system yielded a high maleic anhydride yield (54 %), it proved challenging to separate the catalyst from the reaction mixture. In contrast, heterogeneous catalysts offer distinct advantages over their homogeneous counterparts due to easy separation, product isolation, and reusability across multiple cycles. Various V-based heterogeneous catalysts have been explored for the liquid-phase oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride. Li et al. developed a heterogeneous Mo₄VO₁₄ mixed oxide catalyst for furfural oxidation at 100 °C in acetic acid solvent, achieving a combined yield of 65 % for maleic anhydride and maleic acid [34]. Additionally, other reports highlight the exploration of heterogeneous VO-NH2-GO [35] and VON-GO [36] catalysts for the oxidation of furfural, both of which yielded more than 60 % combined maleic anhydride and maleic acid. The high catalytic activity of V-based catalysts in oxidation reactions is primarily due to their strong redox ability at low reaction temperatures [37]. It is well-known that adding Mo to V and supporting or dispersing them on or in close combination with Al2O3 can enhance the oxidation properties of the catalyst, with Mo playing a crucial role in activating C-H bonds [38,39]. Notably, most of the Mo and V oxide catalysts supported on Al2O3 have traditionally been prepared using solution-based methods, which are time-consuming and generate much environmental waste. An appealing alternative is the development of heterogeneous Al2O3 with closely related Mo and V oxide catalysts prepared via solvent-free methods. In addition, the liquid phase oxidation of furfural was carried out in an acetic acid solvent; however, it is worth noting that the issue of catalyst leaching remains insufficiently documented in most of the reported literature. Recently, Woodfield and coworkers synthesized various single and mixed metal oxides, with a focus on mesoporous alumina, using a solvent-deficient precipitation method (SDP) [40,41]. The method offers simplicity and cost-effectiveness, resulting in high surface areas of metal oxides and mesoporosity without structure-directing agents or surfactants. Notably, mesoporous Pd/Al2O3 [42], Pt/Al2O3 [43,44] and Cu-Al2O3 [45] catalysts have been successfully prepared via the SDP method and applied in diverse catalytic processes. However, there are no reports on the solvent-free synthesis of mesoporous alumina with dispersed molybdenum and vanadium oxide catalysts for liquid-phase furfural oxidation to maleic anhydride. In this study, we prepared mesoporous alumina with closely related dispersed molybdenum and vanadium oxide (MoxVA) catalysts through a simple solvent-free solid-state grinding mixture of Al, Mo and V salts and ammonium bicarbonate followed by calcination. The as-synthesized MoxVA catalysts were used for the oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride in an acetic acid reaction medium. The influence of different reaction parameters (such as Mo/V mole ratio, catalyst calcination temperature, Mo-V catalyst loading, reaction temperature and pressure) was studied to maximize the maleic anhydride yield. Different catalyst characterization techniques were used to understand the structural and surface catalytic properties of the catalyst. Furthermore, catalyst leaching and recyclability studies were conducted to assess catalyst stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9 H2O), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O), ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3), ammonium bicarbonate (NH4HCO3), vanadium pentoxide, molybdenum oxide, maleic anhydride, maleic acid, 2(5 H)-furanone, acetic acid, toluene, dichloromethane, acetonitrile and BMIMCl ionic liquid were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich. γ- Al2O3 was obtained from Sasol. Furfural was acquired from Sigma-Aldrich and was directly used without any further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of mesoporous alumina with dispersed molybdenum and vanadium oxide catalysts Mesoporous alumina-molybdenum and vanadium (MoxVA) catalysts were prepared using a solid-state, solvent-deficient precipitation method [38]. The typical synthesis of the 25 Mo1VA (25 mol% Mo1V1Ox/Al2O3) catalyst involves physically mixing Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (15 g) and NH4HCO3 (9.5 g) with molar ratio of 1:3, along with NH4VO3 (0.392 g) and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O (0.592 g) in a 1:1 mol ratio of Mo to V. Initially, water is released from the hydrated metal salts, and CO2 bubbles from the NH4HCO3 are generated during hand grinding, which completely stops after 20 min of physical mixing. The resulting thick, white-colored wet solid is collected and calcined in a muffle furnace at 600 °C for 5 h, with a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1. Similarly, by varying the Mo/V mole ratio (0.5, 2, and 3) at a fixed catalyst loading of Mo-V (25 mol% of Mo-V on Al2O3), a series of catalysts are prepared following the above procedure. These catalysts are denoted as 25Mo0.5VA (Mo/V = 0.5), 25Mo2VA (Mo/V = 2), and 25 Mo3VA (Mo/V = 3). Additional catalysts are prepared by varying the Mo-V catalyst loading from 5 mol% to 30 mol% on Al2O3. These catalysts are represented as 5Mo1VA (5 mol% Mo1V1Ox/Al2O3), 10Mo1VA (10 mol% Mo1V1Ox/Al2O3), 15Mo1VA (15 mol% Mo1V1Ox/Al2O3), 20Mo1VA (20 mol% Mo1V1Ox/Al2O3), and 30Mo1VA (30 mol% Mo1V1Ox/Al2O3). For comparison, 25 mol% VOx/Al2O3 (25 VA) and 25 mol% MoOx/Al2O3 (25MA) catalysts are also prepared using the same method. 2.3 Synthesis of mesoporous Imp-25Mo1VA catalyst by impregnation method (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O (0.291 g) and NH4VO3 (0.193 g), with a Mo/V mole ratio of 1, was separately dissolved in deionized water (5 mL) at room temperature. After completely dissolving these salts, the two solutions were mixed, and 1 g of Al₂O₃ support (prepared using the method described above) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred at the rate of 300 rpm for 2 h at room temperature. Excess water was removed using a rotary evaporator, and the resulting solid mass was dried overnight at 100 °C. The obtained solid catalyst was then calcined in a muffle furnace at 600 °C for 5 h, with a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1. This catalyst is denoted as Imp-25Mo1VA-S. Similarly, the Imp-25Mo1VA-C catalyst was also prepared by impregnation using a commercial aluminum oxide support for comparison. 2.4 Synthesis of AlVMoO7 and Al2(MoO4)3 catalyst The AlVMoO7 catalyst was synthesized using the solid-state mechanochemical method. This involved taking stoichiometric ratios of Al, V, and Mo oxides. A specific amount of Al2O3 (2 g), V2O5 (3.57 g), and MoO3 (5.65 g) was added to an agate mortar and mechanically mixed using a pestle for approximately 10 min. Subsequently, the resulting solid mixture was transferred into a 50 mL agate grinding jar containing 15 mm diameter agate grinding zirconium balls. Ball-milling was conducted in a planetary ball mill at a rotation speed of 300 rpm for 3 h. The resulting mixed oxide solid mixture was then calcined in a muffle furnace at 650 °C for 12 h with a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1. The obtained ternary oxide (AlVMoO7) catalyst was denoted as BM-AVM. To synthesize Al2(MoO4)3, a predetermined amount of Al2O3 (1 g), and MoO3 (4.24 g) were thoroughly ground together in an agitate mortar and pestle for 10 min. Subsequently, the mixture underwent ball milling using the aforementioned procedure. The resulting solid mixture was calcined at 650 °C for 12 h, with a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1. 2.5 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of catalyst samples were recorded on a Panalytical X′Pert Pro diffractometer with Co Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.7890 Å). The patterns were collected over the range 20° < 2θ < 50°. The phase identification was performed using Match and X′Pert HighScore Plus software. N2 physisorption measurements were performed at −196 °C using Micromeritics Tristar II. Before the measurements, the catalyst samples were degassed overnight at 120 °C. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, and pore size distribution was obtained from the adsorption branch using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method [46]. Raman spectra were recorded using an inVia Reflex Qontor Confocal Raman Microscope with a 532 nm excitation wavelength laser. The spectral acquisition consisted of 1 accumulation of 10 s for each sample. The measured frequency range was 100 – 3000 cm−1. A 384-well plate was used to run these measurements sequentially in an automated set-up using a motorized stage. The X-ray photo electron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out utilizing a Thermo NEXSA XPS system, which employed a monochromatic AlKα source (1486.7 eV). The data was recorded at 19.2 W, with an X-ray beam dimension of 200 × 100 µm. The survey scans were documented at a pass energy of 160 eV, while the high-resolution scans were recorded at a pass energy of 20 eV. Electronic charge neutralization was achieved using a Dual-beam low-energy electron/ion source (Thermo Scientific FG-03). Ion gun current = 150 μA. Ion gun voltage = 45 V. All sample data was recorded at a pressure below 10−8 Torr and a room temperature of 294 K. Data was analysed using CasaXPS v2.3.25PR1.0. Spectra were charge corrected to adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. Regions were fit with a Shirley background prior to component analysis. Symmetric Voight-like line-shapes (LA(1.53, 243)) were used to fit O 1 s, V 2p, Al 2p, and C 1 s. Mo 3d was fitted using the line-shape (LF(1, 1, 35, 280)) as reported in literature[47]. Atomic percentages were calculated using the high-resolution scans. No other major species were noted in the survey scans. The composition of the dispersed and bulk catalysts and the catalyst leaching tests were measured by ICP-OES analysis using an Agilent 5110 ICP-OES instrument. Samples for ICP analysis were prepared by dissolving ca. 30 mg of the catalyst sample, with exact measurements taken for each sample, in 2 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid in a closed vial at 150 °C for 2 h. The mixture was further diluted to 100 mL using ultra-pure water before ICP-OES analysis. Al, V and Mo elements were quantified based on the calibration curves with known standards. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of fresh and the spent 25Mo1VA catalyst was measured in an air atmosphere using a TA instruments SDT Q500 with a 10 °C min−1 scan rate and the gas flow of 60 mL min−1. 2.6 Reaction procedure for catalytic oxidation of furfural In a typical experiment, furfural (2 mmol), acetic acid (10 mL), and the catalyst (50 mg) were loaded into a 100 mL Parr 5500 series reactor and 4848-control system equipped with a glass liner. The reactor was pressurized with 2 MPa of oxygen, and then stirred the reaction mixture at a speed of 500 rpm and heated to 100 °C for 4 h. Kinetic analysis of the 25Mo1VA catalyst was performed at three different reaction temperatures (80 °C, 100 °C and 120 °C) and reaction times ranging from 0.5 to 5 h. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and the gas was collected in a gas bag for off-line qualitative GC analysis. The gas mixture was analyzed using an Agilent 7890B GC equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with a ShinCarbon-ST column (2 m × 1/8 × 2 mm).The solid catalyst was separated from the liquid reaction mixture by filtration, washed several times with water and methanol, and dried at 100 °C overnight for reuse. The liquid product mixture was diluted ten times with acetonitrile and analysed by GC-MS and GC-FID analysis. Initial qualitative product identification was determined by GC-MS. Quantification was initially performed using GC-FID with a ZB-5 column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and subsequently with GC-FID using an HP-5MS column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). To quantify furfural conversion and product yields, an external calibration curve method with known standards was employed. Since determining the maleic acid yield under the analytical conditions of maleic anhydride and other reaction products is challenging, maleic acid yield was calculated by equating the total yields of maleic anhydride before and after the dehydration of the furfural oxidation reaction mixture with an excess of acetic anhydride. Most experiments were conducted in duplicate or triplicate, and furfural conversion and product yields were calculated using the following equations presented below: Furfural conversion ( % ) = moles of furfural reacted initial number of moles of furfural × 100 Specified mole product yield ( % ) = moles of specified product produced initial number of moles of furfural × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = Yield Conversion Carbon mass balance ( % ) = ( C furfural × m final ) + ∑ ( C p × m p ) ( C furfural × m initial ) × 100 Where C furfural = Carbon number of furfural, m intial = moles of furfural initially used in reaction, m final = moles of furfural after reaction, C p = carbon number of specified product, m p = moles of specified product. Estimated CO 2 carbon yield ( % ) = ∑ m C 4 ( m initial × C 5 ) × 100 Where m C 4 = moles of C4 products, m intial = moles of furfural initially used in reaction, C 5 = carbon number of furfural. 2.7 General procedure for dehydration of maleic acid The dehydration reaction of maleic acid to maleic anhydride was carried out according to a reported procedure [33]. After completing the oxidation reaction of furfural to maleic anhydride, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the solid catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture. The mixture was then diluted with an acetonitrile solvent. Next, 5 mL diluted product mixture was transferred into a 100 mL 5500 series reactor and 4848-control system with a glass liner, and 10 mL of acetic anhydride was added. The reactor was pressurized with N2 (0.5 MPa) and heated at 130 °C for 3 h. As a result, the maleic acid produced during the furfural oxidation reaction was completely converted into maleic anhydride, which was analyzed using the GC method described above. The validity of this method was confirmed through a control experiment using pure maleic acid. 2.8 Design of experiments approach for the optimization of catalytic testing parameters A design of experiments, DOE, approach was implemented to identify the optimum experimental conditions for achieving the highest yield of maleic anhydride. The DOE was based on the standard I-optimal method for estimating the parameters of a second order response surface model in the factors being varied in synthesis of the catalysts and catalysis testing experiments. This provides data to describe and test non-linearity in these factors and any simple interactions between pairs of them. It was calculated to include the experimental points from initial scoping experiments using the augmentation protocols available on the JMP v16 (SAS) “Custom Design” platform. 2.9 Catalyst recycling and catalyst regeneration procedure Following the initial reaction cycle, the spent 25Mo1VA catalyst was filtered and washed with deionized water followed by methanol and dried at 100 °C overnight. The mass of catalyst was monitored before the next reaction cycle, with the reaction concentrations adjusted to keep consistent furfural/catalyst and furfural/acetic acid weight ratios and minimize errors when considering the recycling results. The catalyst was cycled through the testing (Section 2.6) and cycling procedure for five reaction cycles. For catalyst regeneration, the recovered spent catalyst after drying was placed in a muffle furnace under static air and calcined at 600 °C for 3 h, with a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1a shows PXRD patterns of 25 MoxVA catalysts (x = 0.5, 1, 2, and 3) synthesized via a solvent-free solid-state grinding method followed by calcination at 600 °C for 5 h. The PXRD patterns for all catalysts indicate the presence of an orthorhombic V2O5 crystalline phase (JCPDS 077–2418) [48,49]. Notably, no crystalline binary or ternary mixed oxide phases were detected in any of these catalysts and suggesting the formation of small highly dispersed MoOx species. To corroborate this, 25 % MoOx/Al2O3 (25 MA) and 25 % VOx/Al2O3 (25 VA) catalysts prepared using the same method and characterized by PXRD (Figure S1) confirm the amorphous nature of the 25 MA catalyst, indicative of highly dispersed MoOx species on mesoporous alumina. In contrast, the 25 VA catalyst exhibits an orthorhombic V2O5 crystalline phase. Raman analysis further elucidates the structure of the 25MoxVA catalysts and is shown in Fig. 1b. The Raman spectra for catalysts with varying Mo/V molar ratios display bands at 141, 198, 283, 305, 409, 475, 525, 702, and 996 cm⁻¹ , consistent with orthorhombic V2O5 [50,51], in agreement with the XRD results. Raman bands at 976 and 842 cm⁻¹ are attributed to MoO3 and confirm the presence of MoOx species [52] . It is important to note that Al2O3 is Raman inactive. Additionally, the Raman bands of the dispersed catalysts are broader while increasing the Mo/V mole ratio of the catalyst compared to bulk V2O5 and MoO3 (Figure S2), indicating the formation of small amorphous particles agreeing with XRD results. In conclusion, both XRD and Raman analyses confirm the presence of V2O5 and MoO3 without any other mixed oxide phases in the studied catalysts. Fig. 2 presents N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves for 25MoxVA catalysts and the prepared Al2O3, with the textural properties reported in Table 1. The Al2O3 displays a type IV isotherm with a hysteresis loop, indicative of mesoporosity. All of the 25MoxVA catalysts show similar adsorption-desorption isotherms, with hysteresis loops resembling Al2O3. Fig. 2b illustrates the pore size distribution for Al2O3 and 25MoxVA catalysts, with average pore diameters ranging from 3.5 to 5.7 nm, and further confirms the mesoporous nature of the materials. The prepared Al2O3 shows a high surface area (252 m²/g) whereas the BET surface areas of 25MoxVA catalysts display an inconsistent pattern when compared to pure Al2O3. Although, a slight decrease in pore volume for the 25MoxVA catalysts suggests partial pore filling of Al2O3 with the dispersed Mo-V oxide species. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to determine the oxidation states of the elements present in the 25MoxVA catalysts and ascertain the atomic composition of the surface. Fig. 3 shows the Al 2p, Mo 3d, and O 1 s/V 2p regions, with component binding energy and atomic percentages given in Table S1. The Al 2p region, given in Fig. 3a, shows two sets of doublet peaks at 74.1–74.3 eV and 75.1–75.7 eV, with the lower energy doublet (74.1–74.3 eV) can be ascribed to bulk Al2O3 (Al-O-Al bonds) [53]. Whereas, the presence of the higher energy species (75.1–75.7 eV), above that of bulk aluminum phases, suggest electronic interaction between dispersed metal species (Mo/V) and Al2O3 (Al-O-M), which corresponds with Parlett et al. and the formation of distinct interfacial Al-O-M species [54]. No discernable differences in oxidation state are noted between the catalysts in the Mo 3d region, with doublet peaks at 232.9–233.01 eV and a spin-orbit splitting of 3.2 eV corresponding to Mo(VI) [47]. The scan region of O 1 s and V 2p slightly overlap in energy, however, deconvolution of the components can be conducted. The O 1 s region for all catalysts contains three components at 530.7–530.9 eV, 531.8–532.1 eV, and 533.1–533.3 eV and are assigned as M-O, M-CO3/M-OH, and Oads with limited differences between the fresh catalysts. For V 2p, all the catalysts show doublet peaks at 517.4–517.5 eV and broadening of the V 2p3/2 associated with Coster-Kronig processes, which are consistent with V(V) oxidation state [55]. The Mo and V oxidation states in the XPS analysis are in agreement with the observed PXRD and Raman results. Surface Mo/V ratios, given in Table S1, are consistent with the increasing Mo molar ratio in the catalysts. However, consideration of the Mo:Al and V:Al surface ratios when compared to the bulk atomic ratio (Table S1), suggests that a physical mixture of small Mo and V dispersed within Al2O3 is formed rather than a truly supported system. In summary, the combination of the presented characterization methods confirms that highly dispersed V(V) and Mo(VI) oxide species which are in close combination with a mesoporous Al2O3 matrix were successfully prepared by a solid-state solvent-free grinding method. The porosity was retained, independent of Mo-V ratios, albeit with a decrease in pore volume when compared to Al2O3 which suggested partial filling of pores with Mo-V species. Furthermore, variation of the Mo-V ratio affected the surface atomic composition but not the crystalline phases or oxidation state of the species present. 3.2 Catalytic activity studies 3.2.1 Effect of Mo/V mole ratio of MoxVA catalysts for the selective oxidation of furfural The effects of varying the Mo/V mole ratio in a series of 25MoxVA catalysts (x = 0.5, 1, 2, 3) on the liquid-phase selective oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride was initially investigated, with catalytic activity results summarized in Table 2. Reactions were conducted under the following conditions: furfural/catalyst ratio (w/w) of 4:1, 2 MPa O2, 100 °C, 4 h, 500 RPM in 10 mL acetic acid, a reported optimal solvent for this reaction [34]. Aside from acetic acid, none of the other solvents (Table S2) studied produced a significant maleic anhydride yield. As the oxidation of furfural proceeds through a radical pathway, acetic acid acts as a radical acceptor to stabilize the reaction intermediates and drives the reaction towards the selective formation of maleic anhydride [33,34]. Individual experiments were conducted for each data point, with the entire reaction mixture collected to ensure reproducibility. In the oxidation of furfural, several oxidation reaction products, including maleic anhydride, maleic acid, 2(5 H)-furanone, and 5-acetoxy-2(5 H)-furanone, were identified over the 25MoxVA catalysts (Table 2, entries 1–4). The literature suggests that furfural oxidation proceeds via a radical pathway [33]. Furfural possesses two potential sites for hydrogen abstraction by oxygen, which are the C1 and C5 carbons ( Scheme 1). Abstraction from C1 could lead to maleic anhydride formation through a 2(5 H)-furanone intermediate. However, a control experiment oxidizing 2(5 H)-furanone under the same conditions used for furfural yielded only 23 % 2(5 H)-furanone conversion and 6 % maleic anhydride, with no other products observed. The absence of 5-acetoxy-2(5 H)-furanone in the 2(5 H)-furanone oxidation experiment suggests that furfural oxidation likely involves multiple pathways, aligning with the findings of Lan et al. [33]. Therefore, the formation of 2(5 H)-furanone and 5-acetoxy-2(5 H)-furanone in furfural oxidation suggests that furfural oxidation likely proceeds through two distinct pathways: (i) hydrogen abstraction at the C1 carbon yielding to 2(5 H)-furanone, and (ii) hydrogen abstraction at the C5 carbon resulting in 5-oxo-2,5-dihydrofuran-2-carbaldehyde. Although this latter intermediate was not detected, possibly due to its instability under the reaction conditions, the significant formation of maleic anhydride strongly indicates that furfural oxidation primarily initiates at the C5 carbon, consistent with previous reports [33]. The water produced during this reaction can then lead to the ring opening of maleic anhydride and the subsequent formation of maleic acid. No formic acid was detected in the liquid reaction mixture, and the presence of CO2 in the gas mixture indicates that the dissociated aldehyde group was completely oxidized. CO2 could also be produced through the overoxidation of furfural or reaction products, with control experiments of the oxidation of furfural, maleic anhydride, maleic acid, and 2(5 H)-furanone conducted to determine any overoxidation and the validity of the estimated CO2 yield. The results showed that maleic anhydride and maleic acid underwent slight overoxidation, yielding 0.6 % and 0.63 % CO₂, respectively, while 2(5 H)-furanone did not produce any detectable CO₂. For furfural oxidation, a slight difference (0.9 %) was observed between the actual CO₂ produced and the estimated yield based on furfural oxidation (Figure S3), suggesting that only minimal overoxidation occurs during the reaction and thus validity of the estimated CO2 yield. It should be noted that the byproducts, 2(5 H)-furanone and 5-acetoxy-2(5 H)-furanone, are also valuable intermediates in the pharmaceutical industry [56]. Despite the formation of several products, a carbon mass balance below 100 % and loss of selectivity indicated the presence of unidentified byproducts. These are attributable to oligomeric species, including humins and a small percentage of overoxidation to CO2. It is well known that furfural inherent instability upon exposure to air leads to polymerization and the formation of humins [33], although, the loss of carbon to humins from various oxidation intermediates cannot be ruled out. However, in the selective formation of maleic anhydride over the various 25MoxVA catalysts (Figure S4), the Mo/V mole ratio proved crucial. Catalysts with Mo/V ratios ranging from 0.5 to 1 (25Mo0.5VA, and 25Mo1VA) achieved over 90 % furfural conversion, but maleic anhydride yields varied significantly. The 25Mo1VA catalyst exhibited the highest maleic anhydride yield (35 %). Further increasing the Mo/V ratio from 2 to 3 (25Mo2VA and 25Mo3VA) resulted in a decrease in both furfural conversion and maleic anhydride yield compared to 25 Mo1VA, suggesting that excessive MoO3 is detrimental to both catalytic activity and selectivity. To elucidate the specific roles of V2O5, MoO3, and the Al2O3 matrix in furfural oxidation, individual catalysts comprising of bulk Al2O3, MoO3, and V2O5 were evaluated (Table 2). While Al2O3 exhibited negligible activity (Table 2, entry 5), MoO3 produced 11 % furfural conversion with trace product formation (Table 2, entry 6). Whereas V2O5 demonstrated higher activity (54 %) but yielded low amounts of maleic anhydride (4 %) and maleic acid (2 %) (Table 2, entry 7). The high activity for V2O5 suggests this is the catalytically active species participating in the oxidation reaction. A physical mixture of MoO3 and V2O5 in equal molar ratios exhibited significantly enhanced furfural conversion (74 %) and maleic anhydride yield (16 %) (Table 2, entry 8). This confirms a synergistic effect between MoO3 and V2O5, with Mo promoting the catalyst redox properties and consequently the conversion of furfural and the selectivity towards molecular products. To further investigate the role of the dispersed species, V2O5 and MoO3 were individually dispersed within an mesoporous alumina via solid-state physical grinding and tested in the selective oxidation of furfural (Table 1, entries 9 & 10). Both dispersed catalysts outperformed the bulk oxides, with the VA catalyst significantly more active (91 %) than the MA catalyst (23 %). However, the single oxide dispersed catalysts achieved significantly lower maleic anhydride yields when compared to the 25MoxVA series. Therefore, this verifies the active role of V, the promotional role of Mo, and the importance of the synergistic interaction between the highly dispersed species. 3.2.2 Effects of Mo-V catalyst loading on alumina, catalyst dosage and initial furfural concentration for the selective oxidation of furfural Having established the optimal Mo/V mole ratio of 1 for the 25Mo1VA catalyst in the selective oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride, the influence of Mo-V catalyst loading was investigated. Catalyst loadings were varied from 5 to 30 mol% while preserving a constant Mo/V ratio of 1. As shown in Fig. 4a, increasing the Mo-V loading from 5 to 25 mol% led to substantial improvements in both furfural conversion and maleic anhydride yield. The 25Mo1VA catalyst achieved a furfural conversion exceeding 94 % and a maleic anhydride yield of 35 %. Concurrently, the formation of maleic acid and 5-acetoxy-2(5 H)-furanone increased with Mo-V loading up to 25 mol%. However, the yield of 2(5 H)-furanone was maximum over the 15Mo1VA catalyst and then decreased with further increase of Mo-V catalyst loading. These results indicate higher loadings facilitated the further oxidation products (Scheme 1) through increased availability of sites. However, further elevating the Mo-V loading to 30 mol% resulted in nearly unchanged furfural conversion, with overall carbon loss to humins and marginally lower maleic anhydride and maleic acid yields than the 25Mo1VA catalyst. Based on these findings, it should be considered that a 25 mol% Mo-V loading is optimal. After determination of the optimal Mo-V loading, the effect of catalyst quantity (25Mo1VA) on furfural oxidation was examined. As illustrated in Fig. 4b, both furfural conversion and maleic anhydride yield increased to a maximum of 95 % and 41 % respectively, as the catalyst dosage was raised from 25 mg to 75 mg. A further increase to 100 mg led to a slight improvement in furfural conversion (97 %) but a minor decrease in maleic anhydride yield (39 %). Thus, the optimal quantity was established to be 75 mg catalyst. The concentration of furfural significantly impacts the selective formation of maleic anhydride over the optimal 25Mo1VA catalyst, while other reaction conditions remained constant. As illustrated in Fig. 4c, furfural conversion increased steadily with rising furfural concentrations (from 0.1 M to 0.4 M), approaching complete conversion at the highest level. However, maleic anhydride production exhibited a different trend. A lower concentration (0.1 M) yielded only 28 % maleic anhydride, which increased to 41 % at 0.2 M but subsequently declined to 35 % at 0.4 M. Byproduct formation also varied with furfural concentration levels, notably, maleic acid, and 2(5 H)-furanone production increased with higher furfural concentrations, while 5-acetoxy-2(5 H)furanone followed a similar pattern to maleic anhydride. Importantly, the overall byproduct yield was substantially higher at elevated furfural concentrations indicating some suppression of humin formation. 3.2.3 Effect of reaction temperature and time To further investigate the influence of reaction parameters and perform a kinetics study, the effect of reaction temperature (80 °C, 100 °C, and 120 °C) and time (0.5–5 h) on the selective oxidation of furfural using 25Mo1VA whilst maintaining constant oxygen pressure (2 MPa O2) and catalyst loading (75 mg) was investigated. As shown in Fig. 5, furfural conversion increased with both increasing temperature and time. However, the conversion of furfural remained significantly low at 80 °C, not exceeding 46 % after 5 h. In contrast, at 100 °C, furfural conversion surpassed 90 % within 3 h and at 120 °C, conversion exceeded 90 % within 30 mins. For all temperatures, the carbon balance is below 100 %, with some loss of carbon to humins under the acidic conditions. The corresponding product distribution was also influenced by alteration of the temperature and time. Maleic anhydride yield was low at 80 °C with a maximum of 14 %, whereas the overall maximum of 41 % was achieved after 4 h at 100 °C. Increasing the temperature to 120 °C resulted in a significant loss of to carbon to humin formation (loss of 72 % after 5 h), suggesting this temperature favors the production of humins due to the fast reaction kinetics, with generated maleic anhydride also polymerized during extended reaction periods. Hence, to balance the efficient transformation of furfural with retaining a higher carbon balance, and therefore generate higher maleic acid yields, the optimal temperature was considered to be 100 °C. 3.2.4 Effect of catalyst calcination temperature The effect of 25Mo1VA catalyst calcination temperature and the influence this exhibits on the catalytic properties was then investigated. Catalysts were prepared with different calcination temperatures and are denoted as 25 Mo1VA-T (where T = 400, 500, 600, and 700 °C). The catalytic performance was evaluated under optimized conditions (100 °C, 2 MPa O₂, 75 mg catalyst, 4 h, 500 RPM). As shown in Fig. 6, all catalysts achieved furfural conversion exceeding 90 %, but product distribution varied considerably with calcination temperature. The 25Mo1VA-400 catalyst produced a 21 % maleic anhydride yield and a significant percentage of 2(5 H)-furanone yield (10 %). Increasing the calcination temperature to 500 and 600 °C markedly enhanced maleic anhydride yields to 28 % and 41 % respectively, with a corresponding decrease in 2(5 H)-furanone yield and indicates enhanced oxidation activity with the formation of further oxidation products. A further increase to 700 °C (25Mo1VA-700) slightly decreased maleic anhydride yield to 37 % compared to the 600 °C catalyst, with promotion of the esterification reaction and loss of carbon products to humins. These results show that calcination at 600 °C optimizes the 25Mo1VA catalyst for selective maleic anhydride production from furfural. The characterization of these catalysts indicates that the observed changes in maleic anhydride yield are correlated to the surface content of V and its proximity to Mo and Al. PXRD measurements (Figure S5) of catalysts calcined at 400, 500, and 600 °C revealed no additional phases beyond orthorhombic V2O5 and the N2 adsorption isotherms showed the decrease of surface area from 389 to 225 m2 g−1 (Table S11). However, XPS analysis (Figure S6) demonstrated the increase of surface V content from 1.5 % to 2.2 % between 500 and 600 °C (Table S12), which is responsible for the enhancement of maleic anhydride yield. The calcination at 700 °C leads to loss of porosity, surface area 15 m2 g−1, and the formation of Al2(MoO4)3 (JSPDS 084–1652) phase alongside V2O5. XPS analysis of 25Mo1VA-700 showed atomic surface V content 2.3 % and Mo/V ratio 0.96. A subsequent control catalysis experiment using pure Al2(MoO4)3 was conducted and yielded less than 5 % maleic anhydride. The combination of these results suggests that the synergy between V2O5 and Al2(MoO4)3 counterbalances the loss of surface area by an order of magnitude making the catalyst 25Mo1VA-700 less selective than 25Mo1VA-600 towards maleic anhydride by only 4 %. The conditions of catalytic experiments and the results from the previous sections have been used as input for an algorithmic design of experiment (DOE) approach to identify the optimum conditions for the highest yield of maleic anhydride. Twenty catalytic tests (Table S14) were run in conditions suggested by DOE and the obtained maximum maleic anhydride yield was 40 %, very similar to what was observed on the previous experiments, 41 %. Thus, DOE approach confirmed that the manually designed optimization was efficient in identifying the experimental conditions for the highest maleic anhydride yield. 3.2.5 Comparison of effects of catalyst synthesis method To evaluate the performance of the 25Mo1VA catalyst prepared via a solvent-free solid-state method, a comparison to a conventional impregnation method (Imp-25 Mo1VA) was conducted. A further comparison of Al2O3 was undertaken, with commercial Al2O3 (Al2O3-C) and the prepared solid state Al2O3 (Al2O3-S) used in the impregnation method. Fig. 7 illustrates a comparison of the catalytic activities of the two preparation methods. All three catalysts achieved furfural conversions exceeding 90 %, with minor differences in product distribution. Notably, the 25Mo1VA catalyst demonstrated superior maleic anhydride production when compared to Imp-25Mo1VA-S and Imp-25Mo1VA-C catalysts. Additionally, the distribution of byproducts varied based on the catalyst preparation method. Overall, the C₄-oxidation product selectivity and carbon balance followed the order 25Mo1VA > Imp-25Mo1VA-S > Imp-25Mo1VA-C. To elucidate differences in catalytic activity, PXRD characterization was performed on the three catalysts, with the PXRD patterns shown in Fig. 8. The Imp-25Mo1VA-S and Imp-25Mo1VA-C catalysts exhibit crystalline phases of Al2(MoO4)3, AlVMoO7 (JCPDS 46–0687), and V2O5. Differences in the ratios of produced phases in the impregnated catalysts can be associated with differences in the crystallinity of the precursor γ-Al2O3 materials (Figure S7). The solid-state prepared Al2O3 shows a lower crystallinity than the commercial Al2O3, which leads to different reactivity in the catalyst synthesis. In contrast, the 25Mo1VA catalyst displays only the V2O5 crystalline phase. The higher maleic anhydride yield of the 25Mo1VA catalyst when compared to the other two catalysts is attributed to higher surface areas (Figure S9 and Table S16), and the strong synergetic interaction between well dispersed V2O5 and MoO3 species with Al2O3. However, the potential contribution of the ternary AlVMoO₇ oxide phase in the impregnated catalysts to furfural oxidation cannot be excluded. 3.2.6 AlVMoO7 catalyst for oxidation of furfural AlVMoO7 has been reported as an active and selective catalyst for methanol and toluene oxidation reactions [38,57]. Therefore, to assess the efficacy of AlVMoO7 in the liquid phase oxidation of furfural, the bulk ternary oxide was synthesized via a mechanochemical solid-state method (BM-AVM). PXRD analysis confirmed the formation of ternary AlVMoO7 oxide (Figure S10), although a trace amount of Al2(MoO4)3 impurity was present. ICP-OES analysis of the BM-AVM catalyst revealed a composition of Al0.99V0.99Mo0.98O7.11, aligning with the expected composition. The BM-AVM catalyst was evaluated for furfural oxidation and compared to the 25Mo1VA catalyst prepared through different methods under optimized conditions. As depicted in Fig. 9, the BM-AVM catalyst was active for furfural oxidation, achieving 86 % conversion and a 24 % maleic anhydride yield. This indicates that the BM-AVM catalyst is much more active and selective than the individual bulk oxide catalysts (Al2O3, MoO3, V2O5) reported in Table 2. However, when compared with the dispersed and supported catalysts (25Mo1VA, Imp-25Mo1VA-S, and Imp-25Mo1VA-C) presented in Fig. 7, both furfural conversion and maleic anhydride yield were lower. Notably, this discrepancy may be attributed to the lower BET surface area and total pore volume of BM-AVM relative to the dispersed and supported catalysts listed in Table S16. Additionally, this bulk AlVMoO7 phase cannot be considered the sole active phase, due to none of this phase being present in the SDP prepared catalysts but further suggests that the synergistic combination of the active metals with an equimolar ratio is required for higher selectivity. 3.2.7 Catalyst leaching tests Catalyst leaching is a significant challenge in heterogeneous catalysis, particularly when reactions occur in acidic media. In order to determine if the solid catalyst is heterogeneously or homogeneously catalyzing the oxidation of furfural under the optimized reaction conditions (100 °C, 2 MPa O2), a hot-filtration test was conducted using a fresh 25Mo1VA catalyst, with the reaction terminated at 1 h and the solid catalyst removed. As illustrated in Fig. 10, after one hour of reaction, a furfural conversion of 46 % and a maleic anhydride yield of 12 % were achieved. The oxidation reaction was continued with the filtrate under identical conditions (100 °C, 2 MPa O2) for a further 1 h. This resulted in a furfural conversion of 50 % and a maleic anhydride yield of 13 %, representing little to no increase in activity. These findings collectively demonstrate that the leached V and Mo species exhibited almost no catalytic activity under the reaction conditions and align with Li et al. study for liquid phase oxidation of furfural using a Mo4VO14 catalyst [34]. In conclusion, the 25Mo1VA catalyst exhibits heterogeneous behavior under the reaction conditions (100 °C, 2 MPa O2, 4 h). Furthermore, to verify the hot-filtration test and determine the extent of catalyst leaching and the effect of the leachate on catalytic activity, leaching tests under optimal conditions (100 °C, 2 MPa O₂, 4 h, 500 RPM) were performed. Initially, a leaching test of the 25Mo1VA catalyst in acetic acid without furfural was conducted at 100 °C, 2 MPa O₂, using 75 mg catalyst for 4 h. The solid catalyst was then removed to eliminate suspended particles and the filtrate collected. ICP-OES of the filtrate (Table S18) confirms that partial leaching of the active V (11.0 %) and Mo (18.4 %) species, with limited leaching of Al (0.9 %), with the majority of solid retained for further reaction cycling. Subsequently, furfural was added to the filtrate, and the reaction was continued at 100 °C and 2 MPa O₂ for 4 h. Analysis of the leached metal reaction showed 24 % furfural conversion and 5 % maleic anhydride yield, significantly lower than the catalytic results with the solid catalyst in Fig. 7. This was further compared to a blank test with only acetic acid and no catalysts, which produced 15 % furfural conversion and 2 % maleic anhydride. Therefore, this indicates that the 25Mo1VA catalyst operates heterogeneously under these conditions to produce a high yield of maleic anhydride and the low proportion of leached species do not homogeneously catalyze the reaction. This procedure was also repeated for the impregnated catalysts, with the leached metals homogeneously catalyzing the oxidation of furfural (Figure S11). This demonstrates improved stability of the SDP prepared catalysts when compared to the impregnated catalysts. 3.2.8 Catalyst recyclability studies After identifying the optimal catalyst composition and heterogenous activity for selectively oxidizing furfural to maleic anhydride, the recyclability of the catalyst was investigated. Following the initial cycle, the spent 25Mo1VA catalyst was filtered and washed with deionized water followed by methanol. The recovered catalyst was then dried at 100 °C overnight and then directly utilized in the next catalytic cycle without any further pretreatment. As depicted in Fig. 11, maleic anhydride yield declined over several cycles, dropping to 14 % after the 5th cycle, although high activity for furfural conversion was retained over all cycles. Additionally, other byproducts, except 2(5)-furanone, also decreased with successive catalytic cycles. The formation of 2(5 H)-furanone initially increased over the first three cycles and then decreased in subsequent cycles indicating a progressive loss of catalytic activity to further oxidation products. The progressive loss of maleic anhydride yield over the successive catalytic cycles is attributed to the coverage on the catalyst surface by deposited polymeric carbon species, which altered the color of the catalyst from yellow to brown (Figure S12). The spent catalyst after the first reaction cycle (S-25Mo1VA) was characterized to determine any changes in catalyst structure but the PXRD patterns (Figure S13) show no difference in phases between fresh and spent catalysts, with only V2O5 present. However, a significant increase in atom percentage of surface carbon species is noted in XPS analysis of the spent catalyst (Table S1). Therefore, TG analysis was performed on both fresh and spent 25Mo1VA catalysts under airflow to confirm the deposition of organic matter on the spent catalyst. As shown in Figure S14, the fresh catalyst displayed a total mass loss of 16.3 % between 30 and 700 °C, primarily attributed to the removal of adsorbed water molecules. In contrast, the spent catalyst after one cycle displayed a 28 % mass loss between 250 and 500 °C, which is attributed to the deposition of humins. A regeneration procedure of the catalyst’s surface (calcination at 600 °C for 3 h) was then applied to the sample after the 1st cycle and the regenerated catalyst was subsequently assessed in the catalytic reaction (Fig. 11). The regenerated catalyst demonstrated yield of maleic anhydride 40 %, which is comparable to the fresh catalyst 41 %, despite the decrease of furfural conversion to 90 % from 95 % of the fresh catalyst. Therefore, the regeneration strategy proposed can be utilized to improve catalytic lifetimes and yields. 4 Conclusions In this study, mesoporous alumina with dispersed molybdenum and vanadium oxide catalysts were synthesized using a solvent-free solid-state grinding method. These catalysts showed high activity in the liquid phase selective oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride. The maleic anhydride yield was significantly influenced by the Mo/V molar ratio, catalyst calcination temperature, Mo-V loading, and catalyst synthesis method. Under optimal conditions (furfural/catalyst 2.56:1 w/w, acetic acid 10 mL, 2 MPa O2, 100 °C, 4 h), the 25Mo1VA catalyst achieved 95 % furfural conversion and a 41 % maleic anhydride yield. The synergistic interaction of V2O5 with Mo and Al in a Mo:V surface ratio of 1, as evidenced by catalyst characterization and activity results, is attributed to the selective production of maleic anhydride. This was supported by the catalytic activity of the ternary oxide AlVMoO₇ and suggests that a close combination of the metals is needed. However, further work is needed to understand the ideal active site local structure for maleic anhydride production. Catalyst leaching tests confirmed the heterogeneous nature of the 25Mo1VA catalyst under optimum reaction conditions (100 °C, 2 MPa O2). The catalyst was recycled several times, with progressive reduction in selectivity. However, the majority of selectivity and activity was restored through a regeneration step and removal of deposited carbon. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic selective oxidation of biomass-derived platform chemicals into monomers offers a sustainable alternative pathway to fossil-based production of chemicals. Herein, mesoporous Al2O3 with dispersed Mo-V oxide catalysts were prepared through a solvent-free solid-state grinding method for the liquid phase oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride. The selective oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride was dependent on the Mo/V mole ratio of the catalyst, catalyst calcination temperature, and catalyst synthesis method. The synergistic interaction of Mo-V with Al2O3 was identified as crucial for enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity towards maleic anhydride. The reusability of the 25Mo1VA catalyst was studied over five catalytic cycles with a progressive loss of maleic anhydride yield due to the formation of surface carbonaceous species. However, the majority of maleic anhydride yield could be recovered utilizing a catalyst regeneration cycle (600 °C, 3 h).

coredata.dc:title: Solvent-free synthesis of mesoporous MoO3-V2O5/Al2O3 catalyst for liquid phase selective oxidation of furfural to maleic anhydride
